content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a nice, easy to understand clash.  I would recommend removing the first 3 paragraphs and replacing it with an introduction that's a lot simpler to read in Clash of Code.  Technically, all the coder needs to do is calculate the current score of the white player.  It has nothing to do with AI, and any mention of AI should probably be removed from the Goal for clarity

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good clash, easy to solve in 5 minutes even for non-Chess players I would think. Not suitable for Reverse, but it seems it's been disabled based on a comment thread below (can't currently see clash information due to a site-wide glitch, but can use IDE).

The addition of the condition for the evaluation to be 0 if the king isn't on the board and the extra point for the bishop pair are nice differentiators to make this puzzle original. Simplifying the problem to only the White pieces balances out the extra work.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good one

Constraints
* Please add "per player" after "two bishops".

Game modes
* It may be too difficult to guess the requirement in Reverse mode.

Thanks.

- Thanks, added "per player".

- The generated stub is a big hint for the Reverse mode, and also I included one test case per piece type.

But maybe I should separate this into two submissions: this one without the reverse mode, and a simpler one just for the reverse mode?

By "simpler" I mean without the king and bishop-pair rules, and simpler testcases (starting with a testcase with just one pawn, then just one knight, then just one bishop, etc)

Thank you.

Yup, what you describe as the simpler idea is the way to go. You would want to show one player's pieces only, step-by-step as you described. Or, maybe something like this:

just one pawn,
just one knight,
one pawn + one knight,
one pawn + one knight + one bishop
etc.

For the current clash, it seems better to disable Reverse mode.
